explanation: Bragg's law describes the conditions for constructive interference of X-rays diffracted by crystal lattice planes. When X-rays with wavelength λ are incident on parallel crystal planes separated by distance d, constructive interference occurs at specific angles θ where the path difference between rays equals an integer multiple of the wavelength. This fundamental law enables X-ray crystallography, allowing determination of crystal structures and atomic arrangements in materials.

definitions.definition: Interplanar spacing between parallel crystal lattice planes.
Bragg angle (angle of incidence measured from the crystal plane).

assumptions.text: The crystal consists of parallel planes of atoms with uniform spacing d.
X-rays are treated as waves with well-defined wavelength λ.
Elastic scattering (no energy loss) occurs at each lattice plane.
The crystal is perfect with no defects or thermal motion considered.
X-rays reflect specularly from each crystal plane.
The incident beam is monochromatic with single wavelength.
Crystal planes are perfectly flat and parallel.

derivation.description: Consider X-rays incident on a set of parallel crystal planes with uniform spacing d.
derivation.equation: text(X-rays incident on parallel planes separated by distance d)

derivation.description: Calculate the path difference between rays reflected from adjacent planes.
derivation.equation: text(Path difference between rays from adjacent planes)

derivation.description: The geometric path difference is 2d sin θ, where θ is measured from the plane.
For constructive interference, this path difference must equal an integer number of wavelengths.
Set the path difference equal to nλ where n is a positive integer.
This gives Bragg's law: nλ = 2d sin θ.
